Last night in class, we discussed that week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter deals with "implacement" and the second, "displacement." In the first chapter, Casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolves around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He argues that using place as the center of culture gives a more grounded community. (This is a very rough summation, a disclaimer in case my professor or any other classmate happens to read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has really grabbed my attention.

GOP gets scolded on recruitment; naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, the citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new Americans. Just before the new citizens left the June 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in ceremony urged them to stop by a voter registration table - a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. However, this table was unusual: those handing out forms were Republican volunteers, and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time to make all of the new voters members of the GOP. All of this was suspicious to Linda Cross, who was there to watch her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely amazing, I have nothing negative to say about this game as it's exceeded my expectations and will probably exceed yours too. The game features fluid movement, is bug- and crash-free, and offers a wealth of story content and options for each day, including multiple practices, events (such as sponsorships), and games. This review is based solely on my experience playing MyCareer, and so far, it's a 10/10. The FaceScan feature worked well for me (I used it twice, although the first attempt resulted in a forehead that resembled Down syndrome). Keep in mind that using the MyNBA2K17 app allows for free FaceScanning and daily VC earnings. #sellout

Magic fans beware... Wizards seems hesitant to create a decent digital game. At its core, Magic: The Gathering is a social game meant to be enjoyed with friends (or frenemies), filled with laughter, trash talk, and game-winning moments. Wizards of the Coast appears to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends, you can't earn gold, which is crucial since it unlocks everything in the game. Understandably, a daily cap has been implemented, but be prepared for a long and boring 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, with whom you can't even communicate. If you choose to play for free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for upwards of a month, playing solo, to unlock the cards.

Being the 3rd installment in the trilogy, I'll address the negative aspects first. I'm not a fan of prequels, as they technically move the story backward rather than forward, which is an issue common to all prequels. However, they do offer more storywise. The combat feels sloppy and lacks the sharpness that Arkham City achieved. As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013), there's a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from being completed, although the main story remains unaffected. Some gadgets are assigned to ridiculous hotkeys, requiring your hand to travel across the entire keyboard to access them. While it may seem minor, this can potentially disrupt your combo during combat.

They basically fixed Shadow Warrior (2013), with awesome boss fights, nice-feeling weapons (maybe not as good as D44M's, but still solid), and enemies that aren't too spongy (if you're not too careless with handling elemental and upgrade stuff). The upgrade system is really balanced, and once you get the hang of it, it's not too tedious. The elemental mechanics and limited ammo gently encourage you to use different weapons. There are many cool, unique (a key difference from Borderlands' 'rng' formula) weapons that remain viable throughout most of the game. The music is great, especially the main theme and, of course, Stan Bush's contributions.

So many things were made wrong. I don't even know how to start this review. This all refers to my career. My player is an outside scorer, a point guard, 1.71m, with maxed stats and all necessary perks. Now, tell me, why does the shooting skill depend on a person's height? Why can a person who is 1.74m not become as good at shooting as a person with 1.71m? I'm 1.87m in real life, made my first player with this height and noticed then that I couldn't reach a higher skill than 89. Why? That's pure discrimination! And why doesn't the game tell me that before I create a character, or even when I reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?

I think this Assassin's Creed nailed the mechanics on all fronts, including ship battles, sailing, hunting, parkour, and more. I felt a stronger attachment to this character as well. Although the story starts out rough, it significantly improves as you progress, which I think is a common trend in the AC series. Edward was an interesting character, and the side characters were equally engaging. I found that the collectibles in this game had a greater purpose and meaning, which I hadn't experienced in previous AC games. While they weren't required, they were enjoyable to collect and provided a balanced reward system.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is alright, as long as you have the money to purchase gun parts, which would be my main complaint with this game: it's pay-to-win. If I could get past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and the HRV is an excellent idea. I'd take this game over any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction format is off-putting for me. If you're alright with this model, then by all means, have fun. But if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, just let this one slide; it's not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death lead to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and I lost my main character around hour 10 of a 20-hour playthrough. I would have really liked a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a third-party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Additionally, the aiming reticule is on the small side and the zoom is underpowered. With all that said, it's been a blast. I'm not normally a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, first-person shooter, and beat-em-up elements is great. I've been playing it as often as I can, always thinking, "Just one more mission, just one more supply run" - or I'm running away and want to get safe before shutting the game down.

An absolutely great strategy game. Having played every single other wargame (European Escalation and ALB), I have to say this one fits well. The number of units is great - I'm not sure exactly how many there are, but there's a huge variety. The graphics are beautiful, the sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is also very entertaining, and I'm not kidding. However, if anyone thinks this game is 'easy', or if you're new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to get the hang of it. Don't get upset, you will lose a lot of units - just make sure you plan ahead, always have anti-air and anti-tank units.

I was initially biased against this game before playing it, and I wasn't even sure about buying it. The portal gun and portal concept seemed weird to me, despite my fondness for science fiction. However, I was pleasantly surprised. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal - just amazing. While it can be cheesy at times, the humor is generally well-executed. Each story character has their own unique sense of humor, and their distinct personalities shine through. The level design is also impressive. Notably, I never played the first Portal game, but I plan to do so if I can spare the time. Playing the sequel actually sparked my interest in the original.

Let's start with the pros and cons, followed by my thoughts on this game. + Some of the best characters + Good story + Loads of content + Customizable character (you can be male or female, whatever you like) + You can have a relationship with most of your companions (yes, fangirls, you can have a love interest) - Bad graphics (I don't think graphics really matter anyway) - Weird and awkward love scenes - Invisible walls - There's one mission that I found boring, but everyone has different tastes - One neutral point: your protagonist can't talk, for those who care. Now, for my thoughts. I love this game. It's probably one of the best RPGs or games in general that I've ever played. So, if you're an RPG fan, you probably already have this game.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet in the UK, just for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back, and instantly recognisable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is also present. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect and very faithful to Generation One. But aside from that, it's actually a very enjoyable game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done, with transforming mid-fight often being a necessity, seamlessly woven into combos, making it quite distinct from High Moon's excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, although some enemies, such as Seekers, require a switch to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it for a little while, but it was nothing special. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing the game. There's a bug where it says there's an update to the terms of service, and whenever you click 'accept', it just pops up again. You have to restart the client for it to work. Although that isn't too bad, I'm not sure why I need to link my Steam and Gface accounts. They claim it's for DLC, but why is that necessary? It's also not reversible, so now I know that a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. The game itself is just average. It's easily recognizable as a COD clone, except somehow they managed to make the gunplay worse... How is that even possible?

4k+ at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo Excellent port and a great entry point if new to the series. Just keep in mind there's lots of (skippable) talking. As usual, I'd suggest using a gamepad, but personally, I had no problems with a keymouse/mouse setup, both of which are completely rebindable. The price is about right, and I wouldn't have been unhappy about a purchase. More than half the DLC is included free, which is still plenty to play with. Recommended game to all JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, provided you don't mind long breaks between the action. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues even at release, and after all these patches, it plays really well. In my opinion, this is a really great and fun game, although the format may be somewhat annoying, where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress the story. I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments, where you can play as Batman and another character, and the ability to use the controller for most segments of the game, but the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments, was greatly appreciated. Driving the Batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing the APC commanders, is actually quite enjoyable once you figure out how to use the brakes to skid around corners, and when you master that, driving around the city is really quite enjoyable.

A damn fine AAA FPS shooter - that's the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays great, with great FPS mechanics, a nice story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and a badass soundtrack. Not for the faint of heart, though - some of those cutscenes were pretty darn cruel and vivid. But when a game is overall so great, it's easier to spot the flaws, and here they are as I saw them: - no SLI support - what the heck? I had to put the game away until I upgraded my card, as it ran too poorly on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. Make sure you have a fairly decent single-GPU card. - Stupidly small obstacles are often unclimbable.

English is not my native language, I am Dutch. Please disregard any typing or grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into a few categories: - graphics - controls - sound - gameplay - replayability. Graphics: The game features a comic-like style. The graphics are very slick, with no unnecessary details and nice color schemes, which totally works for this game. The graphics can be set to 'high' without stressing your system. I run this game on an i5 Pentium processor, with an Nvidia GeForce 710m card and 8GB of memory, and it runs smoothly (Windows 8.1). Controls: The game can be played with a keyboard and mouse, but also with an Xbox controller.

You can see by the hours I put into this game that I thoroughly enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from COD would be. However, don't buy this game thinking it's like COD, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's a game in its own class and should be treated as such. I've lost count of how many times I hear new players complain and get frustrated about getting killed quickly. Oh, the shock of getting shot in the face and dying - it's not like that doesn't happen in real life. Edit: After playing this game for a while now and investing a significant amount of money, I can say it's one of the best multiplayer games around. It's a great alternative to play when you're not in the mood for CS:GO.

I'm 2 hours in and I'm dying from laughter with this game - it's hilarious. The gameplay is solid, the art design is beautiful, the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting, the story and world have me intrigued, and the puzzles are enjoyable. However, the best aspect of this game, beyond all these positives, is its comedic value. If you've played any RPG since the dawn of video game RPGs, you'll appreciate the various jokes, parodies, and references; if you're new to RPGs, you'll still enjoy the game for its humor. If you've played Final Fantasy 7 or X, you absolutely need to play this game - without giving too much away, I had to stop playing after 2 hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.

I'm really sorry, I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I really didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded right up my alley, but the execution fell flat. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this game to be completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress, I still just didn't find the gameplay itself fun. It also lacks a pause button, or if it does have one, I never found it. Considering that many sequences in the game are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel like this game is more cut scene than actual gameplay, and I end up just sitting around waiting a lot.

This game... Phew, where to even start. It was absolutely beautiful, from the story to the graphics - I was hooked. The story wasn't just any story, but actually felt like I was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the story my character was telling. The gameplay was great, and I learned a lot about myself through this game (mainly my fear of heights, which I never had a problem with until the ice caverns). My gut churned the whole time, but I kept going for Uncle Fred! If you guys made a DLC or a second game, I would be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone involved in making this - you made an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization to achieve a certain goal or 'victory'. Unlike previous games, which followed the Earth's timeline through periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age, this game takes place in the future, where you're on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy about this game is that 2K took a new approach and added mechanics like the affinity system and orbital layer. However, I found that these new mechanics could be overwhelming at times. One potential improvement could be incorporating new artwork, such as the environment you experience when communicating with another leader.

Great game! Tons of replayability and very fun zombie survival game! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: After playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more 'realistic' zombie games. It's very much designed like a survival horror, where you must save up your ammo, heal your own wounds when you bleed out, take pills when you're infected, etc. Also, I find the zombies to feel very natural and well animated for a free-to-play game. P.S.: I would recommend getting 1 or 2 friends to play with, but the community is super friendly and you can usually make friends or talk with people in the chat or over voice comms.

02/07/2014 - It's a shame I can't thoroughly recommend or enjoy this game, as from the short time I've played it, I know I'd be addicted if it didn't have the following two game breakers. Firstly, there are no Aussie servers - one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage and creates unbearable lag. Notably, I played through the offline training mode and it was stuttering and lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Coupled with the poor ping, it just ruins the game. Secondly, everything artifacts like crazy - menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never had this happen before with this card and thought it might not like my OC. I set my GPU back to stock and, sure enough, it didn't make a difference.

I finished this very late last night. The story isn't particularly deep or interesting, but the storytelling is what makes it stand out. The atmosphere is rich and immersive, and the numerous collectibles do a great job of fleshing it out. I learned a lot about the world of Batman, so it was a bit disappointing that there were so few bosses in the game. However, there are plenty of future games to rectify that. The combat offers the right amount of challenge, but it's slightly on the easy side. Leveling up Batman wasn't very satisfying, but upgrading and acquiring new gadgets during the campaign adds nice new gameplay mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable places provides a nice sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life, at that. Think Telltale's 'The Walking Dead' is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for 'To the Moon'! Never before have I been so depressed yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I didn't care one bit. Plus, the humor of the game is great as well, and it definitely doesn't intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story... And the 'Doctor Who' references are endless.

Bastion is a bloody brilliant game, with a really great storyline. Set after a calamity has occurred, you start to rebuild on the bastion. There's quite a lot of choice in the game, with options to build structures that give you an advantage, choose which weapons to use, and select power-ups for those weapons, as well as decide which drinks to use for bonus effects. The art style and music in the game are fantastic, with everything looking so colourful at times - who says the apocalypse has to be dull? Best of all, the game features narration that responds to your actions as the player. So, if you pick up a weapon and then switch it for another in the armoury, the narration will reflect this, commenting on your new choice of weapon.

I had originally bought this game in early development, when the only currency was spacebux and there was no 'tech tree'. This was when the game was enjoyable. At that point, all guns were equally overpowered, so there were no issues with imbalance; anyone could kill anyone at any time. The game also used to offer unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You would think that for a game boasting 'bajillions of guns', they would at least provide more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before requiring payment for additional slots. At one point, I had about three pages worth of guns and was planning new ideas for more, as that's where I found the game to be fun.

This game was a surprising gem. One often sees rave reviews of certain products that are often misleading. In this case, the reviews accurately reflect the fun of this neat little game. It's an odd mix between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, and it pulls it off with style. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't normally enjoy in other MOBA games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a try anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked through gameplay. The art style and interface are oddly charming. As a result, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper created from a card set for the game.

I've just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every combat, and they've optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubts about the naval combat system, but it's so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at a time. The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming, just get out of there, regroup, and counter-attack. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for the series' protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the change to their beloved character, it's certainly for the better; and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. DMC serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch. The story follows Dante as he's introduced into the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore.

Where do I even start with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is absolutely charming, with so much detail put into it, making it a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It knows when to be serious, but also isn't a stranger to funny moments. The character design is on point, featuring various characters with unique personalities and secrets. What sets it apart from other RPGs is that you don't have to kill anyone, a refreshingly unused concept in the genre. Drawing inspiration from Earthbound, one of the best RPGs I've seen, it's clear that this game is something special. The soundtrack is also noteworthy, easily the best I've heard in a long time.

I am recommending this solely because it's free, and it might be a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the game did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock factor, but I was neither shocked nor emotionally moved in any way. Maybe I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simple to warrant a reaction from me. The other half of the game attempts to paint a picture (literally) of a person in mental decline, dealing with obsession, hallucination, depression, and a few other themes. In theory, it's a cool idea. However, the game took me only 10 minutes to complete, even with reading and taking in every bit of information I could.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then steps aside. It's an amazing way to test your mind while still being fun. Although this game isn't as story-heavy, it did give birth to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game and beat it when I'm feeling bored, and I love to come back and see what gave birth to a legend and what is a legend. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is quite simple to explain, at least. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. There are two types of buttons in the game: one that you press and one that requires a cube to be placed on it.

If you can overlook the bugs (which I personally only experienced two: one minor and the other quite annoying) - edit: both bugs are now resolved, one fix even increased my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120 - and are looking for a space exploration game, I can definitely recommend this. Since most of these reviews focus on specs, I'll include mine: i5 6600k (~200â‚¬), Radeon RX480 (~200â‚¬), Z170 Pro Gaming (~150â‚¬), and 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70â‚¬) - ~650â‚¬, which is definitely within the medium price range. Although this rig is quite new, I consistently get 60+ FPS on high settings with VSync enabled. I genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments saying they're rocking an overkill setup and getting only 20 FPS.

Remember Age of Mythology? Yeah, it's been that long since there's been an RTS game of such quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander reaches awfully close to the borders of my personal favorite RTS game. Combine this with a huge Risk-like grand strategy mode and it hits the spot. I try not to be overly biased, but the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production, direction, and spawning at the same time, is a major plus. Honestly, I do like complicated RTS games nowadays, like Civ V and so on. However, such games often attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources all into one complicated game mode.

Undertale comes together to make something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title, and the music is nice, but paired together they create truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script runs the gamut from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, and does this while turning RPG tropes on their head. And all of this without touching on the world, characters, story, and gameplay... I could write whole pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you like video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your death, play this game.

I've had this game for only a few months, but in that short time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The developers are very active in the community, and this is evident in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I'm still trying to master; however, this breadth of strategy offers a myriad of ways to achieve goals and capitalize on certain situations. In my opinion, the game is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself fully immersed in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough is going.

Warframe is a fun game for the first few hours of play. After those initial enjoyable hours, you'll begin to notice that the game's offerings are limited to repetition in its combat, enemies, and gameplay. The one major high point for the game is that the developers are working hard and release semi-frequent updates that generally include a lot of content, from sweeping changes to some of the game's systems, new warframes, and other tweaks and features. It's a good game to play casually, though I doubt it will hold your attention beyond a few months unless you enjoy grinding. The upside is that the game is free, so I'd recommend trying it out if you're looking for a quick fix.

This game is extremely boring. I bought it because I believed it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Sadly, it falls far short. In this game, you absorb increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb even more. However, the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, the levels lack inventiveness, and the overall experience is a surreal horror show that's more depressing than entertaining. It makes you question the value of life. Every 'living' creature in the game, from small pets to human beings, is unsettling, making me wonder if the creators had a fascination with taxidermy.

Alright. Let me explain a few things. As a person very interested in politics, I was intrigued when I first heard about this game. I thought, 'Oh wow, a simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!' Well, it really wasn't. The game starts you off and says you need to pick a side: Republican or Democrat, with no option for Independent or third party. A little disappointed, but still optimistic, I carried on to see what I could do. I will give the game credit, though - the character customization, although limited, is pretty fun to mess around with. It's literally the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign.

Fallout 3 had a better storyline. Settlements often get in the way, making you feel like you're babysitting instead of progressing through the story. Some keys are hard-coded and cannot be rebound. The game is plagued by bugs. At one point, my Pip-Boy disappeared permanently, and I had to research console commands to retrieve it. Power armor is easily accessible from the start, and power cores are readily available in trader shops, greatly diminishing its value compared to previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre, and everything about this game is average, except for its stability - it doesn't crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3. However, it's not better than Fallout 3 or New Vegas. The hype surrounding this title is unwarranted, given its overall quality.

My stats (at the time of writing this review): 
- 8.6 hours to reach the end 
- 10 collectibles found out of 25 
- zero achievements out of 15 

What I liked: 
- The visuals, up until the last level (ice caves) 
- Although the story isn't great, the ending (after the closing credits) somewhat redeemed my time spent playing this game 

What I disliked: 
- The visuals in the last level are uninteresting 
- The gameplay in the last level becomes significantly harder, making it a frustrating experience of repetition until you get it right 
- The achievements are too hard, with 13 out of 15 achieved by less than 2.1% of players.

Pros: +graphics. Cons: -bugs (especially environmental issues, such as getting stuck or hitting invisible walls despite having a clear line of sight to the enemy) -the game is overly hand-holding and babysitting -poor AI -enemies always seem to know your location when spotted -enemies have godlike accuracy, which is frustrating, similar to the first Ghost Warrior. -terrible checkpoint and save systems. -a boring story that I couldn't care less about. I wouldn't recommend it unless it's 90% off, and even then, I find playing this game to be an extremely boring chore, only playing to finish it and move on to the next game in my library. Given the time I wasted on the first Ghost Warrior (which was equally boring and left me feeling relieved when I finished it), I probably won't play this one until the end.

Review for 29/11/2015: do not buy this game, as the servers are offline and you can't play. No compres este juego, los servidores estÃ¡n offline. No puedes jugar. While I could play it, I enjoyed it. As the song by the Steve Miller Band goes: "go on take the money and run uh uh uhhh! go on take the money and run..." https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54 --- English - 73 minutes playing the game. OMG, just an hour in and this game is awesome! Some guns are overpowered and matchmaking can be unfair at times, but hey, BF3's matchmaking is worse. As a newbie, I was matched with higher-level players who didn't seem like real humans - you could shoot them in the face and nothing would happen.

Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? :d This puzzle platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who goes around collecting little bits to form a cube and navigating through a fairly large, branching map. The game is quite amusing, and running through it to complete it was a lot of fun. ^_^ However, it can become semi-frustrating if you want to get all the cubes and achievements. To get all the cubes, you'll need to crack codes that you'll have to decipher, which can take a few seconds or frustrate you into looking up a guide (*raises hand* I gave up -_-). The guide, 'A Complete Guide to Fez!!!'

It's not hard for me to see why others like this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing, I have a Vive and I'm much more interested in playing room-sized games with the controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe-inspiring in the scale of its universe, but I also felt that same scale hindered my enjoyment. The learning curve and the time required to do anything interesting at the beginning were both too large for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more time for gaming, this would be compelling to me. But I don't have either, and there are plenty more VR games I'd rather spend my time on.

Hands down, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun Rambo types need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic, with single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always resulting in death, unless it's just a graze. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are required to remain on target. There's no magical ammunition pool - if you reload halfway through your magazine all the time, you'll end up with a pouch full of half-full mags. You can't run forever; sprinting for a while will cause your aim to suffer as you gasp heavily until you catch your breath. Resting your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill can help steady your aim, as accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me start by saying I didn't purchase EU when it first came out, and I got it on sale, which included EW, so I never experienced the issues that some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game, however; it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for XCOM 2, I love it - the game plays pretty well for me on medium, and I'm running a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. At first, the game was set to high, and it was running a bit sluggishly, but not to the point of being unplayable; when I dropped it down to medium, it smoothed out. Not sure if I'm just lucky when it comes to having issues with games or what, but it seems that most of the negative reviews sound like they're coming from some really entitled people.

This game offers RPG levelling, a wide variety of ship types, physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles, and easy-to-learn resource management. It also has a dark humor tone. However, it can be grind-intensive if you underutilize the civilian station types, and the AI teammates are sub-par. Additionally, there's a low variety of equipment types and levelling skills, with no branching options. Despite these drawbacks, the game is incredibly fun. There's still some variety and strategy to be had, and it starts off fast, with plenty of opportunities to unlock new ships or level up skills. The mods, particularly Fight for Universe and Big Fight for Beef, can significantly increase the game's replay value.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the over 20 government leaders and heads of state attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be muted, with anti-globalisation campaigners having called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run in parallel with the WEF's event in Davos.

Deadline nears for Fiat-GM deal. Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on 1 February to settle a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed upon in 2000. GM, whose own European operations are losing money, no longer wants to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, following Monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The US firm is thought to be offering around $2bn (Â£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued that the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to ally with Fiat.

Cardinal criticises Iraq war, saying billions of pounds spent on conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty. Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor made the comments on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance in his Christmas midnight mass. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales used a Christmas message to denounce the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the Archbishop of Canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, he criticised the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment and disease". The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make history poverty".

British stars denied major Oscars. British hopes of winning major Oscars were dashed as UK stars failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's Vera Drake failed to take the director or screenplay awards, and there was no prize for star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet lost to Best Actress Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo failed to win Best Supporting Actor awards. The UK's Andrea Arnold won the short film award for her gritty drama Wasp. Arnold, who presented children's television shows Number 73 and Motormouth in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, the screenwriter and producer best known for her work on the 1970s horror classic Halloween, has died in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it made over $60m (Â£31.3m) worldwide, a record for independent film at that time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she started collaborating with Carpenter. She was widely regarded as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 1970s that were more commonly held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression as fast web access encourages more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of Britain's broadband users regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. The report states that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. With over five million households in the UK having broadband, and this number growing rapidly, the Demos report examined the impact of broadband on people's internet habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband log on to the web before breakfast, while one in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, the report argues, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.

Yukos heads back to US courts. Russian oil and gas company Yukos is due in a US court on Thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by Russian authorities to pay a $27bn (Â£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. The unit was, however, sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm Rosneft, but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now claim the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any company that buys its assets, using all available legal means.

Voters flock to blog awards site; voting is underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed due to an overwhelming number of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top US dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and reports that more than 12,000 are added daily. A new blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing'. The China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the Chinese state press has reported. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the sister Xiluodu Dam, according to the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is one of 30 large-scale construction projects called to a halt due to a lack of proper environmental checks. The Beijing News stated that the company may instead choose to pay a fine. The firm has also ignored orders to stop construction at two of its other projects - the Three Gorges underground power plant and the Three Gorges Project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for not carrying out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.

Manchester City 0-2 Manchester United. Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient, and they managed to fashion just one chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales 'must learn health lessons'. The new health minister for Wales says there are lessons to learn from England in tackling waiting lists. Dr Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the job after Jane Hutt was sacked, admitted "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats said Dr Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile, Ms Hutt defended her record, saying waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda". Dr Gibbons, a former GP in Blaengwynfi, in the Upper Afan Valley, before becoming AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform". One of the biggest problems that had faced Ms Hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve. Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our hardest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with plenty of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed plenty of character and guts and we weren't going to lose." "I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also hailed senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield, which we needed and which no other player has got.

A documentary film about the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be shown at this year's Berlin Film Festival. 'A Different Story' will screen in the Panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10-20 February. The film features the singer candidly discussing both his career and personal life, from his days in Wham! to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February, joined by director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. The 93-minute film sees Michael reflecting on his early days in Wham! and his later career, including his high-profile legal battles with record label Sony and his outspoken stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads enter the US singles chart as digital music downloads are now included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's 'Boulevard of Broken Dreams' is currently number two in Billboard's pop chart and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up the new Hot 100 chart. The second new chart, the Pop 100, also combines airplay, digital, and physical sales, but confines its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music.

The net's self-declared spam king is seeking bankruptcy protection after anti-spam laws took a toll on his business. Scott Richter, the man behind OptinRealBig.com and billions of junk mail messages, stated that lawsuits had forced the company into Chapter 11. OptinRealBig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for Chapter 11 would help it try to resolve its legal problems while continuing to trade. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, OptinRealBig was sued in December 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Mr. Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.

Tottenham Sporting Director Frank Arnesen has denied that Coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "There is only one thing that made him resign, and that is his own personal problems." He has recently spoken to me about this matter, saying it is absolutely personal. Arnesen said he was unable to shed any light on the problems that caused Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added, "Jacques has never gone into exactly what it was, but I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland surged past the Scots as they maintained their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy come to Edinburgh, but they again struggled to turn pressure into points.

Economy to be at heart of Labour's election battle. Britain's economic future will be the focus of Labour's poll campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has stated. He made the comments after Cabinet members held their final meeting at No 10 before the expected election announcement. Brown said voters would acknowledge that Labour had brought stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture", and the Lib Dems provided more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties, urging them not to exploit people's fears during the election. In an open letter, he called on them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA's championships in Sheffield. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not run in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy will hope to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks, establishing himself as one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter, and already seems assured of a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg in the European championships, with Carroll currently ranked number three in the world 3000m rankings, while Cragg occupies top spot.

Robinson targets dual code success as England rugby union captain Jason Robinson aims for dual code success over Australia on Saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international who switched codes in 2000, will lead England against Australia at Twickenham at 1430 GMT. Later, at 1815 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team will face Australia in the final of the Tri-Nations tournament. "Beating the Aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said Robinson. England have the chance to seal their third autumn international victory, following successive wins over Canada and South Africa, as well as gaining revenge for June's 51-15 defeat by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of failure against Australia with a victory at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid website: Net users are being advised to avoid a scam website that claims to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears plausible as it uses an old version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, the DEC has no connection with the fake site and has contacted the police about it. The site is the latest in a long list of scams attempting to cash in on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam email currently circulating, with the subject line "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal" and text that features poor grammar and bad spelling, characteristic of many other phishing attempts.

Iraq to invite phone licence bids. Iraq is to invite bids for two telephone licences, stating it wants to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, Arab and foreign companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications said. The winner will work in partnership with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax and internet services. The ministry said it wants to increase Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate" from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years. It also hopes to develop a "highly visible and dynamic telecommunications sector". Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February. A road-show for investors is also planned in Amman, Jordan.

More women are turning to net security as older people and women increasingly take charge of protecting home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to protect PCs from virus, spam, and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted for net security firm Preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diverse range of surfers. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired, with this number increasing by an average of 13.2% over the last three years. However, more retired women (53%) were purchasing security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing stereotype and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks posed by high-speed broadband net connections to surfers.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs, which is a lot of space to fill. However, more and more iPod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. This phenomenon is called "podcasting," and its strongest proponent is former MTV host and VJ (video jockey) Adam Curry. Podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, although you don't need an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show that podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own home, using just a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet, allowing others to download and listen to them for free.

Andrea Levy, the Orange Prize winner, has seen her book 'Small Island' win the Whitbread Novel of the Year award. She is now the favourite to win the overall prize after beating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's 'The Line of Beauty'. Geraldine McCaughrean has picked up the Children's Fiction award for the third time for 'Not the End of the World'. All category winners will compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which carries a Â£25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will meet on 25 January to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.

Yukos seeks court action on sale. Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that has bought its main asset. Yukos has stated it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20 billion in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal's assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a US court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit remain unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal, which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles, Â£4.8 billion) on Sunday at a state-provoked auction, has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.

Hearts 2-1 Livingston. Hearts wrapped up their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister himself scored the second when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post, putting the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour, but Hearts held on. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken had clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister floated the free kick into the Livi box, and Miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossing to the back post where McAllister raced in to head past Meldrum.

Sun offers processing by the hour. Sun Microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service, allowing customers requiring huge computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun Grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by Sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzz phrase in a company that believes computing capacity is as important a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the development of electricity, suggesting the system could mature in the same way utilities such as electricity and water have developed. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" asked Sun's Chief Operating Officer, Jonathan Schwartz, in a webcast launching Sun's quarterly Network Computing event in California.

Scotland's Justice Minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she intends to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson stated that exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. She praised Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in tackling the problem. However, the minister emphasized that stopping sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm matches is a key objective. Ms Jamieson made the comments ahead of the third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the Executive. Last week, Ms Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

UK debut for Kevin Spacey movie. Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film, Beyond the Sea, in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife, real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri) Headingley, Friday, 25 February 2000 GMT. The Tykes have brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley got the go-ahead after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an unclear future, as the fixed-line phone in your home could soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia shows that an increasing number of people are using their mobile phones for every call they make or take. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now only use a mobile. It revealed that people keep their fixed-line phones because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future was definitely mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls, while conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, often between mobiles and to friends. In the UK, 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.

A group of MPs has attempted to increase pressure on Tony Blair over reform to the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber, in which 70% of members would be elected. Since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats, MPs and peers have failed to agree on reform. The group claims it can win support for removing the last 92 hereditary peers. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers, citing low chances of success due to opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has argued that consensus is necessary for reforms. There have been suggestions that Labour's manifesto will include proposals for changing at least the powers of the Lords.

Disappointed Scott makes solid start. Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equalled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final, having won his heat in 7.64secs but running 0.04secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix Circuit final.

A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a specific date. The unnamed woman from Georgia claims that a chip inside the cartridge informs the printer that it needs refilling, even when it doesn't. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges use chip technology to detect when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. However, the suit claims that the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of whether they are empty.

Virgin Radio offers 3G broadcast. UK broadcaster Virgin Radio says it will become the first station in the world to offer radio via 3G mobiles. The radio station, in partnership with technology firm Sydus, will broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website, enabling the service. James Cridland, Head of New Media at Virgin Radio, said: "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station made available, followed by two digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr Cridland said: "This application will enable anyone, anywhere, to listen to Virgin Radio simply with the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music to appear at Isle of Wight bill. Roxy Music will join Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild at June's Isle of Wight music festival, with REM already confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, taking place from 10-12 June. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will perform on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working in the studio on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year, Roxy Music's first hit was 1972's Virginia Plain, followed by other hits including Street Life, Love Is the Drug, and the 1981 John Lennon cover, Jealous Guy.

Captains line up for aid match. Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is one of four Six Nations captains included in the Northern Hemisphere squad for the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bullock of Scotland, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also in the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod MacQueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. It will be a chance for Woodward to assess some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he said.

The comedy Sideways dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six awards for which it was nominated. It was named Best Film, while Alexander Payne won Best Director and Best Screenplay, along with his writing partner Jim Taylor. The film also won acting awards for its stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. Sideways is tipped to do well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, honor films made outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who took Best Actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama Maria Full of Grace. Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for Maria Full of Grace.

Prince crowned 'top music earner'. Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, beating artists such as Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer banked $56.5m (Â£30.4m) from concerts, album sales, and publishing, thanks to his Musicology tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place, as she earned $54.9m (Â£29.5m) while embarking on her global Re-Invention tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9m (Â£13.4m) last year. "Prince returned to centre stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour took in $90.3m (Â£48.5m) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album, Musicology.

Walmart fights back at accusers. Two big US names have launched advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about their products and corporate behavior. The world's biggest retailer, Walmart, took out more than 100 full-page adverts in national newspapers. The group is trying to counter criticism over its pay deals, benefits package, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, the pharmaceutical group Eli Lilly is planning a campaign against "false" claims about its product Prozac. Walmart kicked off the battle with adverts in newspapers like The Wall Street Journal, featuring an open letter from company president Lee Scott, stating it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth". "There are lots of 'urban legends' going around these days about Walmart, but facts are facts.

Tories have outlined policing plans, under which local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner. The plans, unveiled by the Conservatives, would see the new role replace "inconspicuous" police authorities, according to party leader Michael Howard. He stated that the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Liberal Democrats argued that the plan could allow extreme groups to run policing, while Labour criticised the "extravagant" Tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, Jan Berry, chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, said it was essential that operational independence was retained. "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches," she said. "These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground," she warned.

At a glance: Tory health checks. The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: People coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU will be required to undergo health checks. Those planning to stay six months or more and from countries with high TB rates will need a chest x-ray and further tests if necessary. All individuals from outside the European Union who want to stay a year or more will have to undergo a full medical, which includes tests for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test would automatically result in visa applications being rejected, while other conditions would be dealt with on a case-by-case basis.

Manchester rock band Doves have soared to the top of the UK album chart with their new release, Some Cities, entering at number one. The trio replaces flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the top. The album follows the single Black and White Town, which reached number six. R&B star Nelly has the new number one single with Over and Over, a collaboration with Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, alongside The Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, (Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame, entered the chart at number three, one place ahead of Girls Aloud's Wake Me Up. Hip-hop performer Akon's Locked Up is at number five, while hotly-tipped Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have their second chart hit at number six with Oh My God.

Davies favours Gloucester future, Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to stay with English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but he would prefer to stay where he is. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is only on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proved his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies in the cold, forcing him to take a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he gained match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he admitted before his move to Gloucester that he was angry with the way he was treated.

Cabinet anger at Brown's cash raid: ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated Â£512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr Raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. However, he stated that local governments had to deliver good services without big council tax rises. The central government cash is part of a Â£1bn package to help local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr Raynsford noted that nearly all central government departments had an interest in well-run local authorities.

Israeli club looks to Africa for talent; four African players, including Zimbabwe goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, are set to play for Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin is the first Arab side to ever compete in European competition and will face English Premiership side Newcastle United in the first round. Warriors' goalkeeper Murambadoro, who gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin overcome Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro recently moved to Israel after a brief stint with South African club Hellenic. The club won the Israeli Cup final last season and is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. The club has a strong ethos and is a high-profile promoter of peace and co-operation within Israel.

A new drink limit 'would cut toll' - more lives than previously thought could be saved by cutting drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University College London research claims that cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs are due to vote on the government's Road Safety Bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines, but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, carried out by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, says that cutting the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK's roads compared with 2003. He estimates that this would save the country Â£119m a year. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 Department of Transport document, suggested that such a move could save 50 lives a year.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64Ã—64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1Ã—1 Î¼m^2 diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512Ã—512 Î¼m^2. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline, thereby eliminating the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the entire system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system-optimal (SO) routing by saving on tolls, while user equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HDVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, and the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and HDVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. This capability has not only allowed for the demonstration of quantum behavior in increasingly larger and more tangible objects, but also sparked ideas for utilizing mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing and communication, as well as precision force sensors that operate beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity limits access to a broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals suggested that creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light could overcome this restriction. Although experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems have been achieved, they have yet to access nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews provide product evaluations to inform customer decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated by professional spammers using fake reviews, who continually adapt and develop increasingly sophisticated spamming strategies to evade deployed detectors. Capturing these strategies is challenging, as they can change rapidly over time, vary across spammers and target products, and often remain unknown. Moreover, most existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, which may not align with the ultimate goal of maintaining trustworthy product evaluations. To address these challenges, we propose a minimax game framework where spammers and spam detectors compete to achieve their practical objectives, which extend beyond mere detection accuracy. The Nash equilibria of this game yield stable detectors that are robust to various mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we used the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Among this family, we identified a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We defined a measure of the robustness of an ultra-high fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses was found to be superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we study the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to nonconvexity, multiple local minima exist that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We show that all local minima share a common structural form that partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture, in the sense that each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components.
