Our results apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition and are valid even when the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results in terms of the scaling with the separation between the components.

We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $x_m$ in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first, Berglund-HÃ¼bsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ inside it by a dual group $g^t$. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this work, a generalization of the study of human gait was made from existing models in the literature, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev. This hybrid model combines a strategy of metabolic energy minimization in a race process with a non-linear description of the mass center's libration movement, aiming to reproduce the behavior of the walk-run transition. The results of the experimental data, for different speed regimes, indicate that the perimeter of the mass center's trajectory is a relevant quantity in quantifying this dynamic. An experimental procedure was implemented in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories of the Manuela BeltrÃ¡n University in BogotÃ¡, Colombia.

We present a new mixed-variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems that fully resolves close encounters. The method is based on a time regularisation that maintains the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during planetary encounters. We employ a high-order MVS scheme, enabling integration with large time steps far from close encounters. This algorithm can resolve near-exact collisions, with mutual separations of a fraction of the physical radius, using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed problems, such as the solar system. We demonstrate the long-term behaviour of the algorithm on systems of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering over 50 kyr. Our results show that, for an equivalent computational cost, our algorithm achieves significantly better energy conservation compared to hybrid methods like Mercury.

Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In reality, due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert-space dimension with respect to the system size, it is very challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For n-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires n+1 local measurement settings and can tolerate up to 1/2 white noise. In comparison, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to 1/3 white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution for an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, which has a peculiar multipolar structure that depends only on its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and have a much richer multipolar structure, providing a portal to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger in absolute value than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates can place only mild constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission LISA will improve these bounds by orders of magnitude.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging concept in various domains, including bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common scenario where edges represent either short-term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long-term structural connections (e.g., friendship). In practice, long-term edges are often manually specified by humans, which can be both costly to produce and suboptimal for downstream tasks. To address these issues, we propose a model that combines temporal point processes and variational autoencoders to learn temporal attention between nodes by observing their communication patterns. By driving between-node feature propagation through temporal attention, this approach offers greater flexibility while avoiding the drawbacks associated with manually specified edges.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibrations in a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW) are reported. The PCW consists of two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. Models have been developed and validated for transducing beam motion into phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (GM) of the PCW, for probe frequencies both far from and near the dielectric band edge. Given that our PCW is designed for near-field atom trapping, this research provides a foundation for evaluating potential deleterious effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of PCWs. The long-term goal is to establish strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the GMs of the PCW, thereby enabling quantum-level optomechanics with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in these splittings stems from equivariant stable homotopy theory, as the equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor. Consequently, the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences decompose into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various Euler classes related to the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects lead to a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression are an important source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys, such as Euclid or LSST. In this first paper in a series of two, we use simulations to build a Euclid-like tomographic mock data-set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, both corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we develop an emulator to obtain fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, enabling us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard $\Lambda$CDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those found in child-centered recordings, have been shown to be among the most challenging audio files to process. Nevertheless, building speech processing models that can handle such a wide variety of conditions would be particularly useful for language acquisition studies, in which researchers are interested in the quantity and quality of the speech that children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and measuring the effects of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To this end, we gathered diverse child-centered corpora, totaling 260 hours of recordings and covering 10 languages.

Density-based clustering relies on the idea of linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. The reference to a true, yet unknown, population structure allows the clustering problem to be framed in a standard inferential setting, where the concept of ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, draws a correspondence between the groups and the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required, and a proper selection of the amount of smoothing, which governs the shape of the density and hence possibly the modal structure, is crucial for identifying the final partition. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between the Standard Model and higher-dimensional operators that parameterize the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes pose an obstruction to the naive interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the leading contribution to the total diboson rate correction to cancel. In this case, carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by constructing an asymmetry variable that is only generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is a primary goal of many data analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academic statistics has often been skeptical of data analyses with a causal objective. The introduction of the term "data science" presents a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis in a way that naturally accommodates causal inference from observational data. Like others before us, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three classes of tasks: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (which encompasses causal inference). An explicit classification of data science tasks is necessary to discuss the data, assumptions, and analytics required to successfully accomplish each task. We argue that a failure to adequately describe the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis is a source of widespread misconceptions about data science.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) demands the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard lore is that these particles ensure extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it is unclear what the implications are if this does not occur. This note demonstrates that, for a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS, exact stability of extremal black branes is in tension with rigorously proven quantum information theorems regarding entanglement entropy. Avoiding this contradiction leads to a nonperturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general and does not rely on supersymmetry or a particular UV completion, assuming only the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional systems can give rise to unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures is a major unsolved problem in condensed matter physics. Ultracold two-dimensional Fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, but direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold two-dimensional Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity v$_{\rm c}$. We measure v$_{\rm c}$ as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold Fermi gases as a powerful tool for studying the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

An ordinary differential equation (ODE) is a mathematical model used in various application areas, such as climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, due to its intuitive appeal to modeling. Despite the widespread use of ODEs in modeling, the frequent absence of their analytic solutions makes it challenging to estimate ODE parameters from data, particularly when the model has numerous variables and parameters. This paper proposes a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that is both fast and accurate, even for models with many parameters. The proposed method approximates an ODE model with a state-space model based on the equations of a numerical solver, allowing for fast estimation by avoiding computations of the entire numerical solution in the likelihood. The posterior is obtained using a variational Bayes method, specifically the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Honkela et al.

We study the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in NSN junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an s-wave superconductor. We find that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes strongly depend on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We identify the influence of a chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the junction's transport characteristics. Remarkably, we observe a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions, which is opposite in the two regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been shown to be an effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of a ceramic piece, and this approach has been utilized in various applications. Notably, it provides a method for grading the voltage drop across high-voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. However, a concern for using this method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, particularly if the implanted metal species is prone to oxidation. Here, we report on our examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that after an initial drop of up to 40% in the first few weeks following implantation, the conductivity exhibits only a very slow decrease of approximately 10% over the subsequent year.

We introduce a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, based on the concept of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Additionally, there exist singular configurations that can be identified as n_f=1 baryons charged under this new symmetry. Under this identification, the vector mesons play the role of Chern-Simons vector fields living on the quantum Hall droplet that forms the n_f=1 baryon. We propose that this current is the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal provides a unified picture for the two types of baryons, allowing them to continuously transform into one another in a natural way. Furthermore, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a result of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions offers an intriguing way to combine anomalous Hall and Josephson physics in a single device. We study theoretically how the superposition of both effects impacts the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. Transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface creates sizable transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We generalize the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially established to quantify usual tunneling Josephson current flows, to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are widely adjustable by means of the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a clear spectroscopic fingerprint of Josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface.

Following the suggestion from Monte-Carlo experiments in JimÃ©nez, J. of Turbul. (2020), that dipoles are as crucial to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores, it is found that the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into two distinct families: small, fast-moving cores and larger, slowly moving ones that can be described as 'frozen' into a slowly evolving 'crystal'. The kinematics of both families differ significantly, with only the former exhibiting self-similarity. The latter is responsible for most of the kinetic energy of the flow, and its vortices form the dipoles and streams. Mechanisms for the growth of this slow component are discussed.

Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be an extremely useful framework for designing several quantum algorithms. Often, the running time of quantum algorithms in this framework is characterized by the quantum hitting time, which is the time required by the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with high probability. In this article, we provide improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several continuous-time quantum walk (CTQW)-based quantum algorithms. In particular, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, improving the hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor from O(n^5) to O(n^2 log n). Furthermore, our methods also help to exponentially improve the dependence on precision of the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm to find a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain by Chakraborty et al.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered the main EMRI sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative EMRI formation channel: wet EMRI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the MBH, boosting the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have no information about them, i.e., no interaction with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. Under such circumstances, we still expect our recommender systems to attract users at the first encounter, encouraging them to stay on the website and become active users. This problem falls into the new user cold-start category, which is crucial to a company's development and even survival. Existing works on user cold-start recommendation either require additional user efforts, such as setting up an interview process, or utilize side information, such as user demographics, locations, and social relations. However, users may be unwilling to participate in an interview, and side information on cold-start users is usually not available.

Deep learning has solved many problems that were previously out of reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, despite the fact that current radio systems are well-understood and optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While some gains have been obtained by learning individual parts of a receiver, a more effective approach is to jointly learn the entire receiver. However, this often results in a challenging nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is infeasible to implement. To address this, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, Deeprx, which executes the entire receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant manner. We facilitate accurate channel estimation by constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a specific manner, utilizing both data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs, known as a corpus, from which to generate new inputs through mutation. A corpus of potential seeds often contains thousands of similar inputs, which can lead to wasted fuzzing effort due to exhaustive mutation from all available seeds. To address this, fuzzers are often equipped with distillation tools, such as afl-cmin, that select the smallest subset of seeds triggering the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Common practice suggests that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds results in more efficient fuzzing, a hypothesis we explore systematically. We present the results of over 34 cpu-years of fuzzing using five distillation approaches to understand their impact on finding bugs in real-world software.

In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be divided into several groups, each with similar (isomorphic) state transition structures, allowing them to be relabeled into the same template. Based on this template, a scalable supervisor is designed, whose state size and computational cost are independent of the number of agents, for the case of partial observation. The scalable supervisor under partial observation does not require recomputation, regardless of the number of agents added to or removed from the system. We generalize our earlier results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor at the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations constitute a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for ENF estimation is introduced, utilizing temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. A type of Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is employed, leveraging the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Furthermore, this approach incorporates, for the first time in the field of ENF, a temporal window - not necessarily rectangular - at the stage preceding spectral estimation. Krylov matrices are utilized for fast implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in ENF estimation when a short time window of 1 second is employed in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed approach yields highly accurate results, balancing both time complexity and accuracy.

The direpack package aims to integrate modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the Python universe as a single, consistent package. The dimension reduction methods included fall into three categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. As a corollary, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are also provided, ranging from classical principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. The package contains a set of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, including generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Finally, direpack has been written to be consistent with the scikit-learn API, allowing the estimators to be seamlessly integrated into statistical and/or machine learning pipelines within that framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for high-spatial-resolution optical imaging. Here, we studied the anomalous saturating effect of fluorescence in nitrogen vacancy defects in diamond. Fluorescence reduction was observed with high-power laser excitation, increasing the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission and altering the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We employed a differential excitation protocol to extract high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, the spatial resolution of imaging was improved approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we expect this method can be used to improve the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with defects in solids.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the conventional approach of using individual survey weights (constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference. We develop a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. We compare our approach with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration, revealing that only the Bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and a real data example from a survey of business establishments demonstrate the utility of our approach across various modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a culmination of recent efforts to integrate traditional survey estimation approaches with the Bayesian modeling paradigm, bridging the gap between these two rich but disparate subfields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials---such as ReS2 and ReSe2 monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, and others---have more complex atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials give rise to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as entirely new properties, including ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can also occur due to low symmetry. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic was assembled to highlight recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials.

Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were studied using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was found that in a mesogenic polymer, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of electric birefringence of a melt above the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature can be described by a sum of several exponential processes, with two playing a decisive role. These main processes replace each other over a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also enabled the distinction of two orientational relaxation processes: the first due to rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second associated with the motion of main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated great retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits remains a key focus in deep hashing methods. A common strategy employed in these methods involves adopting an activation function, such as $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, and minimizing a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this approach may cause more and more hash bits to become stuck in the wrong saturated area of the activation functions, never escaping. We refer to this issue as the "dead bits problem" (dbp). Furthermore, existing quantization losses can exacerbate dbp. In this paper, we propose a simple yet effective gradient amplifier that acts before activation functions to alleviate dbp.

We study the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, whose existence is motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry breaking. We consider both the possibility that the triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, or that they decay via mixing with the Standard Model Higgs boson. The former is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and by dark matter direct detection experiments, while the latter is constrained by existing multilepton collider searches. We find that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches, while an unstable triplet with a mass of less than 230 GeV is excluded at a 95% confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than predicted by the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario, also known as "pericenter glow." The standard scenario assumes an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$, whose eccentricity is increased to $e_f$ after the gas disc has dispersed due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. A minor modification of this scenario suggests that narrower belts can form if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, possibly resulting from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, a primordial eccentricity could be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without requiring the presence of planets.

An electron is typically considered to have only one type of kinetic energy, but could it have more, due to its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is well captured at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger-Liquid (TLL) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report on measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using a tunnelling spectroscopy technique. We observe two separate Fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, along with the emergence of three additional 1D 'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by changing the amount of 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

The assembly history of the Milky Way is currently being unveiled thanks to data provided by the Gaia mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the Milky Way has experienced. To this end, we combined the kinematic information provided by Gaia for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. We find that approximately 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

The estimation of a dataset's intrinsic dimension is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces intrinsic, an R package that implements novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of a dataset's intrinsic dimension. Specifically, the methods included in this package are the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To make these novel estimators easily accessible, the package contains a few high-level, intuitive functions that rely on a broader set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic encompasses models that fall into two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category comprises the two-nn and gride models, for which the dedicated functions carry out inference under both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. The second category includes hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising to enable spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Two physical RC systems, based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs), were proposed and modeled to process image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system predictions, respectively. Our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNO to current pulse stimulation demonstrate that an RC system using a single MSM achieves outstanding performance in handwritten digit recognition tasks. Furthermore, complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can also be effectively solved by a physical RC system consisting of 24 STNOs, as confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms, ranging from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we identify a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer items reporting a given signal, the higher the share of overall traffic they collectively attract. This 'few-get-richer' effect emerges in settings with few distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning versus right-leaning news sources), where items are ranked based on their popularity. We demonstrate analytically that the few-get-richer effect occurs when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have heterogeneous preferences for item classes. Using simulations, we analyze how the effect's strength changes with varying assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also experimentally test our predictions in an online experiment with human participants, yielding findings with important implications for understanding the spread of misinformation.

Weight pruning has been widely acknowledged as a straightforward and effective method for eliminating redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), thereby achieving acceleration on various platforms. However, most pruning techniques essentially involve trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, leading to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To address this issue, we introduce a new sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity, which comprises pattern and connectivity sparsity, and achieves both high accuracy and hardware friendliness. With carefully designed patterns, the proposed pruning method consistently and unprecedentedly achieves accuracy enhancement and better feature extraction ability across different DNN structures and datasets. Our pattern-aware pruning framework also enables simultaneous pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training. Our approach, based on the new pattern-based sparsity, naturally fits into compiler optimization for highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs significantly from a treated group is vulnerable to bias from historical events that have different effects on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may result in reduced bias. We investigate this phenomenon through simulation studies. We examine the effect of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that leverages the increase in mrm following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of mrm on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95% confidence interval that encompasses substantial adverse effects, no effect, and small beneficial effects.

When constructing models to summarize clinical data for use in simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models for their capacity to reproduce the data. This can be done through visual predictive checks (VPC), which involve (1) simulating the original study from the model under evaluation multiple times, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is generally straightforward to apply. Here, we consider the application of this method to time-to-event data, with a focus on the special case where a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after the event time.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are presented. We discuss how similar protocols, relying on both repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can be used to: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with Zeno physics. (ii) analytically predict the probability of transferring a quantum system into a target quantum state through stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing the filter functions driving the designed quantum sensor in the frequency domain. Achieving these tasks will enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thereby advancing quantum science and technologies.

I can't think of anyone who has just one interest in life, and that's all they want to do for the rest of their life. Around 15 percent of American workers don't have traditional full-time jobs; they're part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term "side hustle" seems to fit with this ethos, where people are putting together a few different things to make a living. The word "side hustle" has its roots in popular African American newspapers, which used the word "hustle" in the 1920s to refer to some kind of scam. By the 1950s, they were also using "side hustle" to refer to legitimate work. A side hustle is a little different from a second job; a second job is about necessity.

Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is composed of thousands of steel parts, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One imposes itself on the environment, the other creates it. One is designed for nature, the other is designed by nature. Michelangelo said that when he looked at raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be free. The chisel was Michelangelo's only tool. However, living things are not chiseled; they grow. And in our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information required for every other cell to function and replicate. Tools also have consequences. At least since the Industrial Revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people tell you that if you get nervous onstage, you should picture the audience naked? It's supposed to make you feel better. But I was thinking - picturing all of you naked in 2018 feels kind of weird and wrong. We're working hard to move past that kind of thinking, so we need a new method of dealing with stage nerves. And I realized that what I'd really like is to be able to look at you as much as you're looking at me - just to even things out a bit. So if I had way more eyeballs, then we'd all be really comfortable, right?

To do two things at once is to do neither." It's a great smackdown of multitasking, isn't it, often attributed to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, although you know how these things are - he probably never said it. What I'm interested in, though, is: is it true? I mean, it's obviously true for emailing at the dinner table, texting while driving, or possibly live tweeting at a TED talk. But I'd like to argue that for an important kind of activity, doing two things at once - or three or even four - is exactly what we should be aiming for. Look no further than Albert Einstein. In 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers.

I know this is going to sound strange, but I think robots can inspire us to be better humans. See, I grew up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, the home of Bethlehem Steel. My father was an engineer, and when I was growing up, he would teach me how things worked. We would build projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart that we built together - that's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. And one day, he came home when I was about 10 years old, and at the dinner table, he announced that for our next project, we were going to build... a robot.

Sustainability represents the what, the where, and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's most important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices, how I impact them, and how they impact me. I want to know why they fish and how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows us to celebrate the seafood we're fortunate to eat. So, what do we call this? I think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.

The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel, the spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress, and the stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of Christmas past remain recognizable figures from the work of Charles Dickens more than a century after his death. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of Dickens's writing that make it so special? Dickens's fiction is characterized by anticipation, achieved through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features of his work kept his audience wanting more. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals, and only later reprinted as books.

Shah Rukh Khan: Courage, determination, and a single-minded vision - these are the qualities that the biggest achievers have in common. These are the brave hearts for whom failure is not an option. What appears to us as an unconquerable sea is, to our next speaker, an irresistible stage she was born to perform on. So, let's dive straight into the story of our fearless speaker, Bhakti Sharma, who's making waves in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma. (applause) Bhakti Sharma: Imagine, on a scorching Rajasthan summer afternoon, a two-and-a-half-year-old riding on a moped behind her mom, unaware of their destination. And 20 minutes later, that two-and-a-half-year-old finds herself completely submerged in water.

I'm going to discuss a technology currently being developed at Oxford, which we believe will revolutionize the way computer games and Hollywood movies are made. This technology involves simulating humans, complete with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control it. Before I delve deeper into this technology, let's take a brief look at how human characters are currently portrayed in computer games. This is a clip from the game "Grand Theft Auto 3," which we briefly saw yesterday. As you can see, it's a very good game, and one of the most successful of all time.

Like many people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and I were obsessed with the Women's World Cup held in France. Here we were, watching these incredible athletes, with amazing goals, clean and engaging games, and at the same time, outside the field, these women were advocating for equal pay, and in some countries, any pay at all for their sport. Since we were mildly obsessed, we wanted to watch the games live, and we decided that one of the Spanish-speaking networks in the US was the best place to start. It wasn't until a few games into the tournament that a friend of mine mentioned to me, "Why does it feel like everything I'm seeing is commercials for makeup, household cleaning products, and diets?

I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's start with a story about a culture that lived in Micronesia in the early 1900s, called the Yap. I want to tell you about the Yap because their form of money is really interesting. They use limestone discs called Rai stones. The Yap don't actually move these Rai stones around or exchange them the way we do with our coins, because Rai stones can be massive - the largest is about four tons and 12 feet across. So, the Yap just keep track of who owns part of what stone. There's a story about sailors who were transporting a stone across the ocean when they ran into trouble and the stone actually fell in.

You've been accused of a crime you didn't commit. It's impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist on your innocence, you'll likely be found guilty and executed. However, if you confess, apologize, and implicate others, you'll go free. Do you give a false confession or risk a public hanging? This was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor, and a justice system that valued repentance over truth. Salem was settled in 1626 by Puritans, a group of English Protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of Salem, with battles against their Native American neighbors and groups of French settlers being commonplace.

There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren't nearly enough donor organs available to meet that demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? That's the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We're not yet able to print complex organs, but simpler tissues, including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange, are already within our grasp. Bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3D printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.

Good afternoon, I'm proud to be here at TEDxKrakow. I'll try to speak a little bit today about a phenomenon that can, and actually is, changing the world, and its name is people power. I'll start with an anecdote, or for those of you who are Monty Python lovers, a Monty Python-type sketch. Here it is: it's December 15, 2010. Somebody gives you a bet: you will look at a crystal ball and see the future; the future will be accurate, but you need to share it with the world. Okay, curiosity killed the cat, you take the bet, you look at the crystal ball. One hour later, you're sitting in a building of the national TV, in a top show, and you tell the story.

We're going to begin in 1964. Bob Dylan is 23 years old, and his career is just reaching its pinnacle. He's been christened the voice of a generation, and he's churning out classic songs at a seemingly impossible rate. However, there's a small minority of dissenters who claim that Bob Dylan is stealing other people's songs. Fast forward to 2004. Brian Burton, aka Danger Mouse, takes the Beatles' "White Album," combines it with Jay-Z's "The Black Album" to create "The Grey Album." "The Grey Album" becomes an immediate online sensation, and the Beatles' record company sends out countless cease-and-desist letters for "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property." Now, "The Grey Album" is essentially a remix.

That's a rather obvious statement, isn't it? I began with that sentence about 12 years ago, initially in the context of developing countries, but you're here today from every corner of the world. So, if you think of a map of your country, I think you'll realize that for every country on earth, you could draw little circles to identify places where good teachers are reluctant to go. Notably, those are often the places from which trouble originates. We have an ironic problem â€“ good teachers tend to avoid the very places where they're needed the most. I started in 1999 to try and address this problem with a simple experiment in New Delhi.

Currently, most refugees reside in cities rather than in refugee camps. We account for over 60 percent of the global refugee population. Given that the majority of refugees live in urban areas, there is a strong need for a paradigm shift and new thinking. Rather than wasting money on building walls, it would be more effective to invest in programs that empower refugees to help themselves. (applause) We are often forced to leave behind all our possessions, but not our skills and knowledge. If allowed to live a productive life, refugees can help themselves and contribute to the development of their host country. I was born in the city of Bukavu, South Kivu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. I am the fifth of 12 children in my family.

I have two questions for you. One: whose shoulders do you stand on? And two: what do you stand for? These are two questions I always begin my poetry workshops with students, because at times, poetry can seem like a dead art form for old white men who appear to have been born old, like Benjamin Button. I ask my students these two questions, and then I share how I answer them, which is in these three sentences: I am the daughter of black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. These are words I repeat in a mantra before every single poetry performance. In fact, I was doing it in the corner over there, making faces.

(breathes in)(breathes out) So, I didn't always make my living from music. For about five years after graduating from a reputable liberal arts university, this was my day job. (laughter) I was a self-employed living statue, known as the eight-foot bride, and I love telling people I did this for a job, because everyone always wants to know, who are these people in real life. (laughter) Hello. I painted myself white one day, stood on a box, put a hat or a can at my feet, and when someone came by and dropped in money, I handed them a flower â€“ and some intense eye contact. And if they didn't take the flower, I threw in a gesture of sadness and longing as they walked away.

On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This small metal ball, less than two feet in diameter, sparked a space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R. that would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was not actually the first piece of human technology to enter space; that distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket used by Germany in missile attacks against Allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of World War II. Although it was not very effective, at the end of the war, both the U.S. and U.S.S.R. had captured the technology and the scientists who had developed it, and began using them for their own projects.

I am a cultural omnivore, whose daily commute is made possible by an iPod filled with a diverse range of music - from Wagner and Mozart to pop diva Christina Aguilera, country singer Josh Turner, and gangsta rap artist Kirk Franklin, as well as concerti and symphonies. I'm a voracious reader, devouring works by authors ranging from Ian McEwan to Stephanie Meyer, including the Twilight tetralogy. I also live for my home theater, where I indulge in DVDs, video on demand, and a lot of television, with favorites like "Law & Order: SVU," Tina Fey's "30 Rock," and "Judge Judy," where "the people are real, the cases are real, the rulings are final.

Citizens of the world, we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale. Please stand by for a message from the Secretary-General of the United Nations, AntÃ³nio Guterres. The climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a race against time, and we are losing. A growing tide of impatience, especially among young people, is rising due to global inaction. We need more ambition from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors, and people everywhere. I'm pleased you are launching TED Countdown. Your influence and ideas can help accelerate momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050, the only way to avert the worst impacts of global heating. We have the tools, the science, and the resources. Let us now enter this race with the necessary political will and energy.

Menstruation - a simple word describing a natural biological process weighed down by centuries of stigma - has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? As I speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an 'embarrassing' subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, I can tell you that it's exhausting. It's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class, and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings, pretending to be absolutely normal while internally crying out from intense period cramps.

The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the world's largest and most intact forest, Canada's boreal forest. It stretches across northern Canada, including Labrador, which is home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world: the George River caribou herd, numbering approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, when I was there, I couldn't find one, but the antlers serve as proof. Across the boreal, we're blessed with an incredible abundance of wetlands. Globally, wetlands are one of the most endangered ecosystems. They're absolutely critical, as they clean the air, clean the water, sequester large amounts of greenhouse gases, and are home to a huge diversity of species.

Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, comprising fields, plains, and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial realm, having no family other than each other â€“ they didn't even know who their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan, looked different from the others; his skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had been marked with this affliction. One day, while the Supreme Spirit Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck into Yaya's house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted a giant gourd hanging in the corner, but as they tried to look inside, they dropped it.

I had graduated seven years ago from Berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics. I attended a career fair on campus, where I secured an interview with a start-up called Theranos. At the time, there wasn't much information about the company, but what was available was impressive. Essentially, the company was developing a medical device that would allow for a complete blood panel to be run from a finger-stick of blood, eliminating the need for a large needle to be inserted into the arm for blood tests. This was interesting not only because it was less painful, but also because it could potentially open the door to predictive diagnostics.

My journey to become a polar specialist, photographing and specializing in the polar regions, began when I was four years old, when my family moved from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, near Greenland. There, we lived with the Inuit in a tiny Inuit community of 200 people, where we were one of three non-Inuit families. In this community, we didn't have a television, computers, or radio, and we didn't even have a telephone. As a result, I spent all my time outside with the Inuit, playing. The snow and ice were my sandbox, and the Inuit were my teachers. That's where I became truly obsessed with the polar realm.

We're seen as the organization that serves as a last resort for failed social policy. I have no control over who comes to us or how long they stay. We receive individuals for whom all other options have been exhausted, people who have fallen through the cracks of every other social safety net. Since they can't be contained elsewhere, we must. Our role is to contain and control them. Over the years, as a prison system, as a nation, and as a society, we've become very skilled at this, but that's not something to be proud of. Today, we incarcerate more people per capita than any other country in the world. We currently have more black men in prison than were enslaved in 1850.

I'd like to take you on the epic quest of the Rosetta spacecraft. Escorting and landing the probe on a comet has been my passion for the past two years. To do that, I need to explain something about the origin of the solar system. When we go back four and a half billion years, there was a cloud of gas and dust. In the center of this cloud, our sun formed and ignited. Along with that, what we now know as planets, comets, and asteroids formed. What then happened, according to theory, is that when the Earth had cooled down a bit after its formation, comets massively impacted the Earth and delivered water to it. They probably also delivered complex organic material to Earth, and that may have bootstrapped the emergence of life.

Chris Anderson: Hello, TED community, welcome back for another live conversation. This one is particularly significant. When we created our 'Build Back Better' series, our goal was to address the issues arising from the pandemic and imagine how to rebuild from it. However, the events of the past week, including the horrific death of George Floyd and the subsequent daily protests, have added a new sense of urgency that we must address. Can we build back better from this? I think before we can even begin to answer that question, we need to seek to understand the magnitude of this moment. Whitney Pennington Rodgers: That's right, Chris.

In 1903, the President of the United States took a three-day camping trip in California's Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and spent hours talking around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist John Muir. Roosevelt famously loved the outdoors, but Muir had invited him there for more than just camping: Yosemite was in danger. Though Yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley was still at risk of overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-old struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use â€“ two goals that were much easier said than done. The battle over Yosemite began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

Hello. This is my first trip, and the first time in my life I'm outside the walls of Gaza. I'm so happy to be here. (applause) My ambition has always been to be a pilot, to fly a plane, to feel free to fly through the sky, to touch the sky. But that didn't happen. Simply, I live in Gaza, where there is no airport, and all borders are closed on every side. We live in one of the biggest prisons in the world. The only thing I can do is just look up at the sky. On some days, we are lucky if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we make a fire on the front or on the roof of our homes.

I'm sorry I cannot show you my face, because if I do, the bad guys will come for me. My journey started 14 years ago. I was a young reporter, having just graduated from college. Then I got a scoop - a relatively simple story. Police officers were taking bribes from hawkers selling on the streets. As a young reporter, I thought I should approach it differently to have maximum impact, since everyone knew it was happening, yet nothing was being done to stop it. So I decided to go undercover and act as a seller. As part of this, I was able to document hard-core evidence. The impact was great, fantastic. This is what many call immersion journalism, or undercover journalism.

One simple vitamin can reduce your risk of heart disease. Eating chocolate reduces stress in students. A new drug prolongs the lives of patients with a rare disease. Health headlines like these are published every day, sometimes making opposite claims from each other. There can be a disconnect between broad, attention-grabbing headlines and the often specific, incremental results of the medical research they cover. So, how can you avoid being misled by grabby headlines? The best way to assess a headline's credibility is to look at the original research it reports on. We've come up with a hypothetical research scenario for each of these three headlines. Keep watching for the explanation of the first example, then pause at the headline to answer the question. These scenarios are simplified.

When I was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from Ethiopia. One day, my mom asked, "What day should we put for their birthday?" I thought it was a ridiculous question and replied, "The day they were born, obviously?" Then my mom explained, "Well, Kristen, neither of your little brothers has a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out when that was?" I was taken aback. Now, 20 years later, I'm still working on this issue, but instead of trying to solve the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, I'm trying to solve this problem globally. So, what do birth certificates have to do with international development?

Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? That's the question philosopher Robert Nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the Experience Machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that simulates real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch: you have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly notice the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, right?

I would like to share with you the most embarrassing experience I've had during my years as a palliative care physician. This incident occurred a couple of years ago. I was consulted to see a woman in her 70s, a retired English professor, who was suffering from pancreatic cancer. She was experiencing pain, nausea, and vomiting, which prompted the request for my expertise. When I met with her, we discussed her symptoms, and during our consultation, she inquired about the potential benefits of medical marijuana. I reflected on my medical school education, but it didn't take long to realize that I had learned virtually nothing about the subject.

For the past 24 years, I have been a firefighter in Huntington, West Virginia. As firefighters, my team and I are tasked with saving lives and property from disasters such as car wrecks, house fires, and life-threatening medical emergencies. I am a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession. Ten years ago, I decided to increase my medical knowledge and received a nursing degree. This decision was made clear by the realization that the next big threat facing not only my city, but also other cities around the country, was not the one-and-done disaster, where you can ride in like the cavalry as a firefighter, put out the fire, and leave, feeling like you have made a difference and everything is okay.

Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere, and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon. However, over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events, such as volcanic eruptions, release some of the carbon trapped in rock. Meanwhile, human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon.
